awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Empowering Elastic-honeypot as Real-time Malicious Content Sniffers for Social Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Spam messages, misinformation, disinformation and outright fraud are rampant on social networks. To separate out such malicious content from benign and useful content and protect social networks, there is a need for robust content classification systems. However, before such systems can be designed, there is a need for data that train the classifiers. Honeypots are a good way to obtain such data about malicious attacker behavior. Conventional honeypots rely on manually created artificial user accounts as lures to trap attack activities. However, such honeypots are often identified easily by smart attackers. They also suffer from lack of deployment flexibility, feature variability, network scalability, and system portability. This project develops a novel and lightweight honeypot-based malicious content capturing system that cannot be easily bypassed by attackers. The honeypot is then used to intelligently gather and automatically classify contents into likely malicious and likely benign. The goal is to mitigate the adverse effects of malicious contents and sanitize social environments, significantly elevating the security and trust of social networks. Research datasets and software toolkits are shared with the broader research community. The research findings are transitioned into educational materials in the form of book chapters and hands-on classroom materials, delivered to students at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette and also shared with other universities worldwide. The project also involves undergraduate and under-represented students for research experience. 

This project develops a novel and lightweight honeypot-based malicious content sniffing system, named the elastic-honeypot sniffer, to overcome drawbacks in conventional honeypot-based solutions. Two core components constitute the elastic-honeypot sniffer: (1) real-time data gathering and (2) elastic-honeypot detector. Using robust learning techniques on existing spam datasets, the project identifies features and behavior profiles of users who are found to be lucrative targets for spammers. For real-time data gathering, the elastic-honeypot dynamically deploys artificial user accounts as lures based on the learnt vulnerable user profiles to trap attackers intelligently. The main advantages over conventional honeypot technology are node availability, deployment flexibility, features variability, network scalability, and system portability.  The data captured by the elastic-honeypot sniffer is used to design robust classification techniques to differentiate between malicious and benign content that are resilient against adversarial attacks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The rampant spammy behaviors keep attacking the social networks and annoying users, which have been grossly detrimental to social medias, by impacting the quality of users' experience, incurring economic loss, or even swinging victims' political opinions. It remains challenging and in urgent need to have new and effective solutions for malicious users or contents capturing so as to sanitize social environments.

In this project, we have developed a real-time malicious content gathering system, named elastic-honeypot system, for intelligently gathering social network contents with high potential of including malicious behaviors. We have carefully identified the features and patterns that attract malicious users' taste and used them to select the normal users possessing them to serve as our elastic-honeypot nodes. Our system has been running on Twitter for three years, collecting over 20 million tweets, of which 7 million tweets have been labeled for use. It was also deployed into Instagram to collect 600,00 pictures in total.  Using the collected data, we have devised a collection of solutions to improve the classification accuracy from different perspectives. The advanced solutions for more malicious features and patterns discovery have been developed by us. For example, we have proposed a cascade variational auto-encoder mechanism guided by the Bayesian structure to discover more latent features which can capture the hierarchically entangled features, for empowering our classification. We have also used the knowledge graph to extract the multi-relation among entities to better learn the network contents' relationships for classification.  Moreover, we have tackled the challenge of imbalanced malicious contents classification, which is common in most social platforms where the malicious contents account for only a small portion of all contents. We devised the outlier-based solution to exhibit malicious contents' patterns at the outlier and isolate them. We also proposed the minority synthesis approach and the information-preservable undersampling approach to balance the datasets for better classifications. Our solutions exhibited the promising performance with extensive experiments.

The outcome of this project provides new solutions to mitigate the adverse effect of malicious contents and sanitize social environments, which thus can significantly benefit to society and business. Multiple Ph.D. and undergraduate students are supported by this project, which enrich their training and learning for the cutting-edge research. The nine-week summer tutorial course (Machine Learning: Application and Practices) has been held for undergraduate students in Summer 2021 and Summer 2022, for delivering the research outcomes, the gathered dataset, and the developed codes to them. More than thirty undergraduate students have actively participated this summer tutorial course.

 


Last Modified: 06/25/2023
Modified by: Xu Yuan
